cards.title: Community in the woods / Runnymede eco-village

item.title: Runnymede eco-village
item.trailText: The Surrey site that is home to Diggers 2012 – named after land activists who took over or squatted on commons and fields during the English civil war
item.standFirst: The residents of the Runnymede eco-village believe modern living is fundamentally broken and decided they wanted nothing to do with it. On the side of Cooper’s Hill, under the cover of oak, sycamore and birch trees, Danielle Zalcman photographed the community in the woods. This four-acre plot of disused land, 30 miles west of London, has been home to the Diggers since 2012, who are named after a group of land activists who took over or squatted on commons and fields during the English civil war. The group has a court hearing on Monday morning to decide on eviction proceedings

displayImages.caption: The longhouse. Photograph: Daniella Zalcman/www.dan.iella.net
displayImages.altText: The longhouse
displayImages.cleanCaption: The longhouse.

displayImages.caption: The fire by the longhouse is the centre of communal activity in Runnymede. There is a constant stream of people stopping for tea, for a meal, to warm up by the fire, or to catch up with the others. Photograph: Daniella Zalcman/www.dan.iella.net
displayImages.altText: The fire by the longhouse is the centere of communal activity in Runnymede
displayImages.cleanCaption: The fire by the longhouse is the centre of communal activity in Runnymede. There is a constant stream of people stopping for tea, for a meal, to warm up by the fire, or to catch up with the others.

displayImages.caption: A police officer stops to chat and have a cup of tea. Photograph: Daniella Zalcman/www.dan.iella.net
displayImages.altText: A different police officer stops to chat and have a cup of tea. Unlike in the US, most British law enforcement don’t carry weapons, which creates a noticeably more relaxed dynamic
displayImages.cleanCaption: A police officer stops to chat and have a cup of tea.

displayImages.caption: Keleigh looks over a map of Yorkley Court in the Forest of Dean, a similar community that is also fighting imminent eviction. The Diggers will routinely organise group trips to other eco-villages, either to learn new skills or to show support when other communities are threatened. Photograph: Daniella Zalcman/www.dan.iella.net
displayImages.altText: Keleigh looks over a map of Yorkley Court in the Forest of Dean, a similar community thats also fighting imminent eviction. The Diggers will routinely organize group trips to other eco villages, either to learn new skills or to show support when other communities are threatened.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Keleigh looks over a map of Yorkley Court in the Forest of Dean, a similar community that is also fighting imminent eviction. The Diggers will routinely organise group trips to other eco-villages, either to learn new skills or to show support when other communities are threatened.

displayImages.caption: Rosie in the longhouse. Photograph: Daniella Zalcman/www.dan.iella.net
displayImages.altText: Rosie in the longhouse
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rosie in the longhouse.

displayImages.caption:
Community members are divided between those who want to move on and find a new, more secure place to live, and those who want to stay and take a stand during eviction. Many long-time residents have already left, including Andrew Brackenborough, thought to be one of the village’s founders.

On this afternoon, five Diggers set out to visit other potential sites in the area that could serve as a new home Photograph: Daniella Zalcman/www.dan.iella.net
displayImages.altText: Diggers set out to check out other potential sites in the area that could potentially serve as a new home

On this afternoon, five Diggers set out to visit other potential sites in the area that could serve as a new home

displayImages.caption: Arun by the longhouse. He is one of several Diggers who work during the week. He largely uses the income to support his teenage daughter  otherwise, he doesn’t have much use for money.

cards.title: Tate Modern / Turbine Hall daubed with graffiti by BP protesters
cards.rawTitle: Turbine Hall daubed with graffiti by BP protesters

item.title: Tate Modern's Turbine Hall daubed with graffiti by protesters against BP sponsorship
item.trailText: Activists occupied the Tate Modern's Turbine Hall overnight on Saturday in protest at the gallery's sponsorship by oil company BP
item.standFirst: Activists occupied the Tate Modern's Turbine Hall overnight on Saturday in protest at the gallery's sponsorship by oil company BP. The 75 demonstrators from the Liberate Tate group, dressed in black with veils covering their faces, spent 25 hours scrawling words of warning about climate change in charcoal on the sloping floor of the hall. They refused to leave the building when it closed and were eventually allowed to stay overnight. They left at lunchtime on Sunday

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Activists occupy Tate's Turbine Hall in protest against BP sponsorship - video Photograph: guardian.co.uk

item.title: Le Mans 24 hours
item.trailText: Nico Hülkenberg became the first active Formula 1 driver to win Le Mans for 24 years as he partnered England’s Nick Tandy to victory in a Porsche
item.standFirst: Nico Hülkenberg became the first active F1 driver to win Le Mans for 24 years as he partnered England’s Nick Tandy to victory in a Porsche

displayImages.caption: Drivers and cars line up in the traditional herrringbone formation before the start.
displayImages.altText: Drivers and cars line up in the traditional herrringbone formation before the start.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Drivers and cars line up in the traditional herrringbone formation before the start.

displayImages.caption: Porsche dominated qualifying, locking out the front three places on the grid, here the No17 and No18 head the front row.
displayImages.altText: Porsche dominated qualifying. locking out the front three places on the grid, here the No17 and No18 head the front row.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Porsche dominated qualifying, locking out the front three places on the grid, here the No17 and No18 head the front row.

displayImages.caption: And they’re off – the 55-car field streams into the first corner as the first lap and the first minute of the 24 Hours begins.
displayImages.altText: And they’re off - the 55-car field streams into the first corner as the first lap and the first minute of the 24 Hours begins.
displayImages.cleanCaption: And they’re off – the 55-car field streams into the first corner as the first lap and the first minute of the 24 Hours begins.

displayImages.caption: Heading up the hill towards Dunlop, clear skies and sunshine accompanied some fierce racing in the opening six hours.
displayImages.altText: Heading up the hill towards Dunlop, clear skies and sunshine accomapanied some fierce raciing in the opening six hours.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Heading up the hill towards Dunlop, clear skies and sunshine accompanied some fierce racing in the opening six hours.

displayImages.caption: Nissan brought a new front-engined, front-wheel drive to Le Mans and although they struggeld for pace the No22 car did make it to the chequered flag.
displayImages.altText: Nissan brought a new front-engined, front-wheel drive to Le Mans and although they struggeld for pace the No22 car did make it to the chequered flag.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nissan brought a new front-engined, front-wheel drive to Le Mans and although they struggeld for pace the No22 car did make it to the chequered flag.

displayImages.caption: The Nissan crew get to grips with a recalcitrant engine in a bid to make the finish.
displayImages.altText: The Nissan crew get to grips with a recalcitrant engine in a bid to make the finish.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Nissan crew get to grips with a recalcitrant engine in a bid to make the finish.

displayImages.caption: Bollards beware as the Extreme Speeds Motorsports car takes a spin at the first Mulsanne Chicane.
displayImages.altText: Bollards beware as the Extreme Speeds Motorsports car takes a spin at the first Mulsanne Chicane.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bollards beware as the Extreme Speeds Motorsports car takes a spin at the first Mulsanne Chicane.

displayImages.caption: Audi could not continue their extraordinary run of success at Le Mans, having won 13 times since 2000, but did see all three cars to the finish, including taking a podium, with third place.
displayImages.altText: Audi could not continue their extraordinry run of success at Le Mans, having won 13 times since 2000, but did see all three cars to the finish, including taking a podium, with third place.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Audi could not continue their extraordinary run of success at Le Mans, having won 13 times since 2000, but did see all three cars to the finish, including taking a podium, with third place.

displayImages.caption: Pegasus racing show their continued support for Jules Bianchi, the driver who suffered a terrible accident at last year’s Japanese Grand Prix.
displayImages.altText: Pegasus racing show their continued support for Jules Bianchi, the driver who suffered a terrible accident at last year’s Japanese Grand Prix.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Pegasus racing show their continued support for Jules Bianchi, the driver who suffered a terrible accident at last year’s Japanese Grand Prix.

displayImages.caption: But ultimately the race belonged to Porsche, with the No19 car running flawlessly and at real pace from third on the grid to take the victory after 24 hours.
displayImages.altText: But ultimately the race belonged to Porsche, with the No19 car running flawlessly and at real pace from third on the grid. to take the victory after 24 hours.
displayImages.cleanCaption: But ultimately the race belonged to Porsche, with the No19 car running flawlessly and at real pace from third on the grid to take the victory after 24 hours.

displayImages.caption: Dusk falls and the lap times go down as well as the air temperature drops, powering this Aston Martin into the night.
displayImages.altText: Dusk falls and the lap tmes go down as well as the air temperature drops, powering this Aston Martin into the night.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dusk falls and the lap times go down as well as the air temperature drops, powering this Aston Martin into the night.

displayImages.caption: Boasting a special Le Mans livery the Aston Martin ‘Art Car’ catches the eye of spectators.
displayImages.altText: Boasting a special Le Mans livery the Aston Martin “Art Car” catches the eye of spectators.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Boasting a special Le Mans livery the Aston Martin ‘Art Car’ catches the eye of spectators.

displayImages.caption: The Corvette No64 speeds into the daylight hours, the car would go on to win the class in GTE Pro.

displayImages.cleanCaption: The Corvette No64 speeds into the daylight hours, the car would go on to win the class in GTE Pro.

cards.title: Syria / Desperate refugees flood into Turkey

item.title: Syrian refugees cross into Turkey
item.trailText: Thousands of Syrians fleeing heavy fighting between Islamic State militants and Kurdish forces are crossing into Turkey near the border at Akcakale
item.standFirst: Thousands of Syrians fleeing heavy fighting between Islamic State militants and Kurdish forces are crossing into Turkey near the border at Akcakale

displayImages.caption: Islamic State fighters order people back to the Syrian city of Tal Abyad after they tried to enter Turkey through the border crossing at Akcakale on Sunday 14 June 2015. Thousands of refugees are fleeing fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces in northern Syria. Photograph: Bulent Kilic/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Isis Akcakale
displayImages.cleanCaption: Islamic State fighters order people back to the Syrian city of Tal Abyad after they tried to enter Turkey through the border crossing at Akcakale on Sunday 14 June 2015. Thousands of refugees are fleeing fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces in northern Syria.

displayImages.caption: Syrians fleeing through broken fences to enter Turkish territory at Akcakale border crossing on 14 June 2015.  Photograph: Bulent Kilic/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Syrians fleeing through broken fences to enter Turkish territory at Akcakale border crossing on 14 June 2015.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Syrians fleeing through broken fences to enter Turkish territory at Akcakale border crossing on 14 June 2015.

displayImages.caption: A woman crosses the Syrian-Turkish border at Akcakale on 14 June 2015. Turkey said it was taking measures to limit the flow of Syrian refugees onto its territory. Photograph: Bulent Kilic/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A woman crosses the Syrian-Turkish border at Akcakale on 14 June 2015. Turkey said it was taking measures to limit the flow of Syrian refugees onto its territory.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A woman crosses the Syrian-Turkish border at Akcakale on 14 June 2015. Turkey said it was taking measures to limit the flow of Syrian refugees onto its territory.

displayImages.cleanCaption: Syrians fleeing the war pass through border fences into Turkey.

displayImages.altText: Syrians fleeing the war rush through broken down border fences to enter Turkish territory at Akcakale in the south-eastern Turkish province of Sanliurfa.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Syrians fleeing the war rush through broken down border fences to enter Turkish territory at Akcakale in the south-eastern Turkish province of Sanliurfa.

displayImages.altText: A Syrian man fleeing the war carries a child over the border into Turkey.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A Syrian man fleeing the war carries a child over the border into Turkey.

displayImages.caption: Under an open-door policy, Turkey has taken in 1.8 million Syrian refugees since the conflict in Syria erupted in 2011. Photograph: Bulent Kilic/AFP/Getty Images

displayImages.cleanCaption: Under an open-door policy, Turkey has taken in 1.8 million Syrian refugees since the conflict in Syria erupted in 2011.

displayImages.altText: A Syrian child fleeing the war is helped as she enters Turkish territory.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A Syrian child fleeing the war is helped as she enters Turkish territory.

displayImages.caption: Syrian refugees near the Syrian town of Tal Abyad try to grab bottles of water thrown from the Turkish side of the border at Akcakale. Photograph: Bulent Kilic/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Syrian refugees near the Syrian town of Tal Abyad try to grab bottles of water thrown from the Turkish side of the border at Akcakale.

cards.title: Video / Crocodiles fight-to-the-death in Kakadu national park
cards.rawTitle: Crocodiles fight-to-the-death in Kakadu national park

item.title: Massive crocodile snaps up rival after fight to the death in Kakadu national park
item.trailText: When Maxi, a 4.5m long saltwater crocodile, fought with a smaller saltie, there was only ever going to be one winner
item.standFirst: When Maxi, a 4.5m long saltwater crocodile, fought with a smaller saltie, there was only ever going to be one winner. Afterwards, the dominant croc holds its kill in the water until it is completely still. It is rare to witness this behaviour, even though the crocodiles of the Northern Territory's Yellow Water Billabong are territorial by nature

stillImage.caption: Maxi, a saltwater crocodile in Kakadu National Park, Australia, holds his kill. 15 June 2015 Photograph: Helen Davidson for the Guardian Photograph: Helen Davidson/Guardian
stillImage.cleanCaption: Maxi, a saltwater crocodile in Kakadu National Park, Australia, holds his kill. 15 June 2015 Photograph: Helen Davidson for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Maxi, a saltwater crocodile in Kakadu National Park, Australia, holds his kill. 15 June 2015 Photograph: Helen Davidson for the Guardian Photograph: Helen Davidson/Guardian
displayImages.altText: crocodile
displayImages.cleanCaption: Maxi, a saltwater crocodile in Kakadu National Park, Australia, holds his kill. 15 June 2015 Photograph: Helen Davidson for the Guardian

image.altText: crocodile
image.cleanCaption: Maxi, a saltwater crocodile in Kakadu National Park, Australia, holds his kill. 15 June 2015 Photograph: Helen Davidson for the Guardian

cards.title: Millions of mayflies create 'blizzard' in Pennsylvania town
cards.rawTitle: Millions of mayflies create 'blizzard' in Pennsylvania town

item.title: Millions of mayflies create 'blizzard' in Pennsylvania town
item.trailText: This video from Wrightsville fire department shows what it calls the mayfly 'blizzard' emergency which responders experienced on Saturday night
item.standFirst: This video from Wrightsville fire department shows what it calls the mayfly 'blizzard' emergency which responders experienced on Saturday night. They explain: 'This video does no justice of the feeling, smell, and sounds of millions of mayflies. Several accidents were caused by how slick the road surface became'

stillImage.caption: Emergency crews in Wrightsville respond to mayfly blizzard. 15 June 2015 Photograph: Todd Nissly/Wrightsville Fire Department Photograph: Todd Nissly/Wrightsville Fire Department
stillImage.cleanCaption: Emergency crews in Wrightsville respond to mayfly blizzard. 15 June 2015 Photograph: Todd Nissly/Wrightsville Fire Department

cards.title: Hillary, Prodigy and pottery / The weekend in pictures

item.title: The weekend in pictures
item.trailText: A selection of the best pictures from around the world this weekend
item.standFirst: A selection of the best pictures from around the world this weekend, including the start of Hillary Clinton’s election campaign and Dave Grohl’s broken leg

displayImages.caption:
Karo, Indonesia
Mount Sinabung erupts Photograph: Rony Muharrman/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Karo, Indonesia Hot ash is emitted during an eruption of Mount Sinabung
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Karo, Indonesia
Mount Sinabung erupts

displayImages.caption:
Hong Kong, China
People listen to speeches at a pro-democracy rally Photograph: Dale de la Rey/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Hong Kong, China People listen to speeches during a pro-democracy rally
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Hong Kong, China
People listen to speeches at a pro-democracy rally
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Dale de la Rey/AFP/Getty Images

displayImages.caption:
Menton, France
A group of migrants wrap themselves in emergency blankets on the border with Italy Photograph: Jean-Pierre Amet/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Menton, France A group of migrants keep themselves warm with emergency blankets on the seawall on the border with Italy. 200 mainly African migrants attempted to cross the border on Saturday but were blocked by Italian police and French gendarmes.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Menton, France
A group of migrants wrap themselves in emergency blankets on the border with Italy

displayImages.altText: Gothenburg, Sweden Dave Grohl, lead singer of the Foo Fighters, is seen on a screen as he addresses fans from the photographers' pit after falling and breaking his leg during the band's show at Nya Ullevi. Grohl returned to the stage after receiving treatment and completed his set.
